tn.text: "because of my love for Jonathan"
Jonathan was Saul's son and David's best friend.
This is the name of a man. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Ziba calls himself "your servant" to show great respect to David.

tn.ref: I may show the kindness of God
tn.text: The abstract noun "kindness" can be stated as "kind." AT: "I may be kind as I promised God I would be"

tn.ref: who is lame in his feet
tn.text: "whose feet are damaged." The word "feet" here refers to the ability to walk. AT: "who is unable to walk" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
These are names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a place. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
It is understood that David sent messengers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
Translate this as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:2sa:04:04|4:4]].
The word "came" can be translated as "went." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_go]])
Mephibosheth refers to himself as "your servant" to show great honor to David.
"because I loved your father, Jonathan"

tn.ref: you will always eat at my table
tn.text: Here "my table" represents being together with David or in his presence. Eating with the king at his table was a great honor. AT: "you will always eat with me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: What is your servant, that you should look with favor on such a dead dog as I am?
tn.text: This rhetorical question shows that Mephibosheth understands that he is not important enough for the king to take care of him. This can be translated as a statement. AT: "I am like a dead dog. I do not deserve for you to be kind to me." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

Here Mephibosheth represents the line of Saul, and he compares himself to a "dead dog." Dogs were feral animals, not cared for, and of little importance. A dead dog would be considered even less important. AT: "such a person like me who is worthless as a dead dog" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: must always eat at my table
tn.text: Here "my table" represents being together with David or in his presence. Eating with the king at his table was a great honor. AT: "must always eat with me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "now" makes a break in the main storyline. The narrator gives background information about Ziba. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
"15 sons and 20 servants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: Your servant will do all that my master the king commands his servant
tn.text: Ziba refers to himself as "your servant" and refers to David as "my master." AT: "I, your servant will do all that you, my king, command me to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
This is the name of the son of Mephibosheth. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: all who lived in the house of Ziba
tn.text: Here "house" represents Ziba's family. AT: "all of Ziba's family" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: he always ate at the king's table
tn.text: Here "table" represents being together with David or in his presence. Eating with the king at his table was a great honor. AT: "he always ate with the king at his table" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: though he was lame in both his feet
tn.text: "thouge both of his feet were damaged." Here "feet" represents the ability to walk. AT: "though he was unable to walk" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
